userreviews.userReview: I don't know if I can read another Miss Julia book. What was laugh-out-loud funny in the first book never quite made it for me in this one. I was immediately tired of Miss Julia's self-absorption, inability to listen, and misjudgment.
Sometimes you just need a little fluff. These books just make me feel warm and fuzzy inside. It's nice when a problem can be solved in 200 pages or less. Love Miss Julia.
An absolute pleasure to read. I love Miss Julia!

Once again I laughed out loud through this silly, but hilarious book. There was a lot of information about NASCAR drivers and races, which I know nothing about, and don't have much interest in, but it didn't detract from the story.There is nothing like a Miss Julia book to get one's mind away from daily stresses! Love it!

This is the 2nd in this series and the last for me. Cute and clever but definitely NOT compelling.Boring and annoying at times.Bookclub #2 choice. Borrowed book from library. Had to renew twice just to get through it.
Apparently some people think Miss Julia is a pip; I think she is a pill.

I have become very fond of these little books. The biggest reason is that the author lives 30 minutes away in Hendersonville, NC. Miss Julia is an elderly woman who is just now finding her place in this world and the story of her tangling with NASCAR is pretty funny. As with the first of this series, the relationship she has with her late husband's mistress and their son is the core of the story and does not disappoint. I can't wait to watch "Little Lloyd" grow up in the remaining books. Whenever the latest "Miss Julia" book comes out, it is a celebration at the library in which I work. The patrons, many elderly themselves, flock to her stories. As will I as I work myself through the series.

I really enjoyed "Miss Julia Speaks her Mind," so I was anxious to read the rest of the series. While I enjoyed this second installemnt, I found Miss Julia a little annoying in this one. Her "speaking out," was getting on my nerves because it was directed at someone who was trying to help her. The outspokeness was endearing in the first novel because the people really deserved to be told off. Her evasion of the law made me uncomfortable, and I couldn't get into the little romances - there wasn't enough build up for them to be believable. I had predicted the ending half way into the novel as well. So all in all it was pretty disappointing, but still a fun, lighthearted read.
I didn't like this book nearly as much as the first one in the series. I've heard they get better after this one. I hope so!

The second book in this series. Miss Julia doesn't know what to do when Hazel Marie doesn't come home from her date with church fundraiser Wilson T. Hodge. After the police won't help her she hires private investigator J.D. Pickens but only if she and Little Lloyd can help in the search. These books are a lot of fun. I don't think I'd want to read too many in a row but I enjoy visiting Miss Julia.
I'm really enjoying this series with the no-nonsense, out-spoken Miss Julia. There's also the added bonus of being set in my home state of North Carolina. On to book #3.

Poor Mr. Pickens! Ms. Julia was determined to hold him accountable for doing his job. I love Miss Julia's relationship with Little Lloyd & Lillian. When Lillian asks Julia about Little Lloyd missing school, she said not to worry about that. "He's so far ahead of the others, his absence'll give them time to catch up." I also liked when Lillian told Miss Julia "This ain't no time to be weaken' down on us" when Miss Julia was worried about losing Little Lloyd. Lillian gave Miss Julia's arm a shake and went on to say "You hear me, now." I loved when she was trying to point out the advantages of being a widow to another widow.

This okay book would have been pretty good if it had been half as long. It's full of Miss Julia's ridiculous long-winded rants to the point of being tedious to the nth degree. (Yes, I expected some rants - it's a Miss Julia book after all!) But I did finish it amid loud whines of "Oh no, not another page!"

I didn't enjoy this one near as much as the first. Love the writing, love Miss Julia, just didn't love the plot or the new character of the PI. He was annoying but apparently will be a recurring character. Onto another Miss Julia book!
Miss Julia continues to muddle her way through peoples lives, but the author does put her in unusual situations.
Sucks.
Miss Julia makes me tired. Don't think I can read any more of these. And she certainly goes to a different Presbyterian church than I do!
If you love- " I Love Lucy" then Miss Julia Books are for you! Hilarious hi-jinks!
pretty much my rating. it was okay. really liked the first one. we'll see about the 3rd.

This book didn't live up to my expectations from book 1 in the series. I also have the same impression of Miss Julia Springer of Abbotsville, North Carolina as I have of Agatha Raisin - I find it hard to like this character. In book 2 Miss Julia is more sharp-tongued, self-righteous, abrasive, opinionated, bossy, rude, feisty and with a goal is to keep everyone she knows on her version of the straight and narrow path. Most mystery books (murder or otherwise) have a theme, and this one is no exception - it's theme is NASCAR racing.Hazel Marie Puckett and her son, Little Lloyd, are happily living with Miss Julia now. Hazel Marie had been her deceased husband's mistress and Little Lloyd was their son. In Christian charity Miss Julia took them in and has learned to love them both. The pastor of the church across the street has been instructing Hazel Marie in the Presbyterian catechism which becomes part of the climax. One night she goes to dinner and the movies with Wilson T. Hodge, the church fundraiser, and never returns home. She doesn't even call to say she has been delayed. The next day Miss Julia goes to the police to declare her missing, but Lieutenant Peavy tells her to call a private investigator because he doesn't consider her missing yet. Miss Julia hires J.D. Pickens to find Hazel Marie. She doesn't tell him, until he's hired, that she and Little Lloyd are going to tag along and help in the search. She doesn't trust him yet and wants to know his every move. He is, of course, annoyed and unappreciative of the help. In the meantime, a sheriff's deputy arrives to serve papers on the missing Hazel Marie and a snatch and grab order on Little Lloyd. Her sleazy televangelist uncle, Brother Vern, has filed a complaint alleging that Hazel Marie is an unfit mother and that Little Lloyd should be taken away from her. His ulterior motive is Little Lloyd's inheritance. Now Miss Julia is desperate to find Hazel Marie in time for the court date and to hide Little Lloyd from the law. Hazel Marie finally calls and asks for help, but the phone is disconnected as she says she's at the Big-----. It doesn't take long for J.D. and a clue Hazel Marie left behind to steer him to a connection with NASCAR racing and two competing race teams heading by race drivers Jerry Johnson (who turns out to be a friend of J.D.'s) and Bobby Bigelow who has stolen a lucky charm from Johnson. One of the funniest scenes in the book is Miss Julia and Little Lloyd rescuing Hazel Marie and the resultant high-speed car chase between Miss Julia driving and an RV on a banked NASCAR track.The climax happens during an ice storm at the Presbyterian church across from Miss Julia's house with everyone in attendance including the competing race car drivers. The tables are turned on the sanctimonious pastor and Brother Vern and they see the error of their ways - maybe. Subplots include:- Sam Murdock, Miss Julia's former lawyer, has broken his leg and has a young, blond, sexy home health aide named Etta Mae Wiggins attending him. Miss Julia's jealousy rears it's ugly head.- Miss Julia's friend, LuAnne Conover, needs advice about her husband who has a male problem that is affecting her love life. Proper Miss Julia is appalled when she finds LuAnne flirting with Jerry Johnson, the race car driver.- After Hazel Marie is rescued, J.D. Pickens is enamored with her. Will he appear in future books?Returning characters are Lillian, Miss Julia's maid and witty confidant; and Deputy Coleman Bates who rents a room at Miss Julia's house and is dating Binkie, her current lawyer.There were some funny moments, but the main problem I have with this book is how Christians are portrayed. They seem to be manipulators, hypocrites, busy bodies, liars, etc. with no redeeming values. Just an OK read. I hope the author hits her stride and the next in the series meets my expectations.

This was a good book.When Miss Julia burst on the scene in her fictional debut, Miss Julia Speaks Her Mind, this proper lady of a certain age found her orderly world turned upside down when Hazel Marie Puckett appeared with her nine-year-old son, Little Lloyd, who looked disturbingly similar to Miss Julia's late husband. Now, in Miss Julia Takes Over, with her sharp tongue and iron backbone intact, Miss Julia must tackle another disruption when Hazel Marie doesn't return from a dinner date with a fund-raiser who, in Miss Julia's opinion, wears his shorts too tight. Frantic and unable to persuade the local police that Hazel Marie is in danger, Miss Julia hires J. D. Pickens to investigate, despite her reservations about his taste for beer and women. She and Little Lloyd help search for Hazel Marie, running into adventures ranging from a most indelicate display of fisticuffs to a high-speed car chase on the track of a NASCAR Speedway, all the while standing strong ...because if Miss Julia doesn't take care of things, who will?

Hazel Marie is missing and Brother Vern is threatening to take Little Lloyd. Miss Julia gets no help from the police so she hires J. D. Pickens to find Hazel Marie. Pickens has never had a client like Miss Julia. She insists on knowing his every move and accompanying him everywhere he goes AND she drags Little Lloyd along. Can he find Hazel Marie because of or in spite of Miss Julia?There’s lots of dialogue and action here which I like in a book. I like strong female protagonists and Miss Julia certainly has the character for such a role. I loved watching her perspectives change in the book as she began to accept less than her measure of perfection in people and began to see things in shades of gray rather than always black and white. Good clean reading, recommend.

Kind of a cozy mystery, as long as you can stomach the acerbic, overly self-righteous main character of Miss Julia. I imagined her as a cross between the 3 Golden Girls (not Blanche, there's no dithering, vapid Blanche here). One of the reviewers on the back described her as the northern version of Miss Daisy, and that's pretty much on target. I enjoyed it, tho I did roll my eyes a few times at her know-it-all attitude and condescending comments -- all meant for the betterment of the receiver, of course. (*eye roll*)

I love Miss Julia and this one is as much fun as the first one. Hazel Marie is missing and Miss Julia can't get any satisfaction from her local law enforcement so she hires a PI to help and Little Lloyd hunt for his mother. The fact that Uncle Vern is trying to get custody of Little Lloyd doesn't help either. Many adventures and misadventures ensue. Another not to be missed story with Miss Julia

I only gave it four stars because I felt like it was a little long. In my opinion, the author could have trimmed off about 40 pages. However, that being said, I did enjoy the story. I love Miss Julia's personality as well as Hazel Marie's, Little Lloyd's and Lillian's. I especially like the fact that Miss Julia is willing to change her opinions on matters. It's a feel-good series that runs along the lines of the Mitford series.

Miss Julia is, in my opinion, rather annoying in this book. The last 50 pages were pretty good, I was tempted to skip to the last chapter and move on but I am glad I didn't because they were perhaps the best. The rest of the book dragged on. Miss Julia's spunk was flat out rudeness in this book. This book was way too long and it almost turns me off to the series. You could probably skip it and be okay.

This book wasn’t on3 of the better ones in this series, but am glad I read it. I honestly didn’t finish it simply because I lost interest in it, but will ne day go back and finish it. The author does get better the more books she writes about miss Julia. Just because I didn’t finish this book I can still recommend it to my friends, just don’t base the entire series on this one book

Miss Julia is at it again! I enjoyed this book although I would have loved Lillian to have been in the book more. Mr. Pickens was a fun character though and it looks like he will be back again. I'm hoping the whole Pastor Ledbetter/Brother Vern storylines aren't continually revisited in every book. That storyline is already getting old.

I didn’t like this one as much as the first one. Once Hazel Marie was found, I felt that the story should have ended, but it kept going. I’m also confused as to why Miss Julia is still attending her Pastor Ledbetter’s church; that’s not very believable to me. I will keep reading this series and hope that the next book is better than this one.

I loved this prim and proper lady who is surrounded by people who are anything but. She certainly believes in "if you want it done right, you have to do it yourself." She is this private detective's worse nightmare but could be his best friend. The interaction between these two is hilarious, especially when he takes an interest in things, she doesn't want him interested in.

description: As soon as readers met Miss Julia in Miss Julia Speaks Her Mind, this Southern woman of a certain age and with an iron backbone and Steel Magnolia poise became an instant favorite. In that debut book, Miss Julia's proper existence was interrupted by the sudden appearance of a close "friend" of her deceased husband. Hazel Marie, with "heels too high, a dress too short, and hair too yellow", showed up on Miss Julia's doorstep, bringing scandal, adventure, and nine-year-old Little Lloyd into her life. Now, in Miss Julia Takes Over, she's Little Lloyd's guardian and fast friends with his mother. So she's frantic when Hazel Marie disappears after a dinner date with a church fund-raiser, who, in Miss Julia's opinion, wears his shorts too tight: "nobody can be th at upright and pious without trouble going on underneath". Since the sheriff won't help her, Miss Julia takes matters into her own hands and, with Little Lloyd in tow, finds herself tracking Hazel Marie all across North Carolina. From a most ungenteel display of fisticuffs to a hair-raising car chase, Miss Julia stands strong and forges ahead. Because . . . if Miss Julia doesn't take care of things, who will?
